Class DateUtil

public class DateUtil
extends java.lang.Object

Kitchen sink of static methods used for date and times

Method Detail

getEligibleDaysBetweenTwoDates

public static int getEligibleDaysBetweenTwoDates(java.util.GregorianCalendar dateAtOneEnd,
                                                 java.util.GregorianCalendar dateAtOtherEnd,
                                                 boolean[] dayEligibility)
                                          throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Calculates the number of eligible days between two dates, inclusively. If the dateAtOneEnd and dateAtOtherEnd are identical, the function will return 1 if this date is eligible and 0 if it is not.

Iterates over days, so use subtraction if you are concerned about performance for very long intervals.

Parameters:
dateAtOneEnd - date at one end of interval
dateAtOtherEnd - date at other end of interval, must be in same time zone as dateAtOneEnd
dayEligibility - boolean array of length 7, with each day corresponding to a day of the week, where true indicates the day is eligible. Index 0 is Sunday.
Returns:
the number of eligible days between dateAtOneEnd and dateAtOtherEnd, inclusively. Note that is dateAtOneEnd equals dateAtOtherEnd, 1 will be returned if the date is eligible and 0 if it is not.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if dates are in multiple time zones or dayEligibility boolean not of length seven or entirely false

getDaysBetweenTwoDates

public static int getDaysBetweenTwoDates(java.util.GregorianCalendar dateAtOneEnd,
                                         java.util.GregorianCalendar dateAtOtherEnd)
                                  throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

getWeekendDaysBetweenTwoDates

public static int getWeekendDaysBetweenTwoDates(java.util.GregorianCalendar dateAtOneEnd,
                                                java.util.GregorianCalendar dateAtOtherEnd)
                                         throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Calculates the number of weekend days between two dates, inclusively. If the dateAtOneEnd and dateAtOtherEnd are identical, the function will return 1 if this date is eligible and 0 if it is not.

Iterates over days, so use subtraction if you are concerned about performance for very long intervals

getEligibleDaysInArray

public static int getEligibleDaysInArray(java.lang.Iterable<java.util.GregorianCalendar> dates,
                                         boolean[] dayEligibility)
                                  throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Calculates the number of eligible days in an array of GregorianCalendar objects. Note that duplicates will only be counted once, as will two objects that fall in the same date.

Note that all dates must be in the same time zone, or an exception will be thrown.

Parameters:
dates - array of days to determine if eligible
dayEligibility - boolean array of length 7, with each day corresponding to a day of the week, where true indicates the day is eligible. Index 0 is Sunday.
Returns:
the number of eligible days in an array of GregorianCalendar objects
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if dates are in multiple time zones or dayEligibility boolean not of length seven or entirely false

getDaysInArray

public static int getDaysInArray(java.lang.Iterable<java.util.GregorianCalendar> dates)
                          throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Calculates the number of days in an array of GregorianCalendar objects. Note that duplicates will only be counted once, as will two objects in the same date.

This will be used instead of just finding the array length to eliminate counting elements in the same day more than once.

Note that all dates must be in the same time zone, or an exception will be thrown.

Parameters:
dates - array of days to determine if eligible
Returns:
the number of eligible days in an array of GregorianCalendar objects
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if dates are in multiple time zones

                              throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Calculates the number of weekdays in an array of GregorianCalendar objects. Note that duplicates will only be counted once, as will two objects in the same date.

Note that all dates must be in the same time zone, or an exception will be thrown.

Parameters:
dates - array of days to determine if eligible
Returns:
the number of eligible days in an array of GregorianCalendar objects
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if dates are in multiple time zones

Take date string in "yyyy/mm/dd" format and see if it is valid

Parameters:
yyyySlashmmSlashdd - date in "yyyy/mm/dd" format
Returns:
